ID: CRITIQUE OF PURE REASON
The Critique of Pure Reason is arranged around several basic distinctions. After the two Prefaces (the A edition Preface of 1781 and the B edition Preface of 1787) and the Introduction

ID: Doctrine of Elements
The Doctrine of Elements sets out the a priori products of the mind

ID: Doctrine of Methods
The Doctrine of Method contains four sections. The first section

ID: Trascendental Analytic
The Transcendental Analytic sets forth the appropriate uses of a priori concepts

ID: Trascendental Dialectic
The Transcendental Dialectic describes the transcendental illusion behind the misuse of these principles in attempts to apply them to realms beyond sense experience. Kant’s most significant arguments are the   Paralogisms of Pure Reason

ID: Trascendental Aesthetic
Trascendental Logic
